wsm2506

Anyone tried it or use it?
 
 I have it and normally run it simultaneously with IE6. It seems to be just a hair faster than IE6. It also has good pop-up control.
 
 My only suggestion for them would be for them to incorporate "auto-hide" in the full screen mode for the toolbar and favorites menu. If they had that, I would probably stop using IE6 altogether.
 
 Other opinions?

I had our tech guy install firefox on all work comptuers 2 weeks ago and disable (as far as you can ) IE. No complaints so far from anybody. There were a few issues the first week, mostly folks who were unfamiliar with tabbed browsing. 
 
 Also, did they just institute center click for new window open/close? I coul dhave sworn it didn't work in the last release, but I am not seeing it in th eupdate log.
Missouri Mule

That's all I've used for the past several months. But some web sites are not yet set up for it. I don't like the "favorites" at all, and they need to fix that. It gets cluttered up too easily and you can't delete en masse and that is a pain in the buttocks to put it mildly. But on balance I like it and also use its companion Thunderbird. Recommended.
wilted_laughter
Firefox is the only thing i use now.
daewoo

I started using it almost exclusively several months ago. I ended up making the transition for our entire company becuase I employ a bunch of slackers ho surf the internet endlessly when they should be working. Spyware was a real problem.
 
 The amount of spyware that adaware finds is less than 1/20 of what it was before, and now that everybody has a 3 button mouse (which is a must have for tabbed browsing) everybody seems happy with the changes. Additionally, I LOVE the ad filter and the fact that when you install it, it imports EVERYTHING including password lists and cookies (older versions did not do this). 
 
 I use an air gapped computer for things like forum surfing and some of my general web surfing, and the air gapped machine is on dial up. The Ad filter cuts down on load times considerably. The flash filter is also good for dialup folks (keeps pages from loading flash stuff, replaces it with a "play" button instead so it only downlods it if you want to see it).
maco

Firefox's main advantage is that it is far more secure, or fewer people are going after it, either way you'll have fewer problems, for now.

 Yep yep. I use Mozilla. It's the same company. And it really is more secure, even if people were going after it. IE has ActiveX capabilities (among other [dangerou] capabilities) that open up lots of holes in security. You can shut those options off, of course. Moz doesn't even let them be on so there's no chance of a hack through them. ActiveX's are needed to watch videos on Yahoo's Launch, but that's about it. In that case I go for Netscape (same browser as Moz but with ActiveX). I like Moz better than FF just because the Google bar and address bar are one on Moz and separate on FF. Moz/FF are soooo much faster than IE too. And it takes less comp. memory. I can have one Moz window with like 10 tabs and not slow down at all. 10 separate IE windows though? That's gonna slow me down a bit.
